content.webTitle: A Radical Romance by Alison Light review – a tender but oblique memoir

fields.headline: A Radical Romance by Alison Light review – a tender but oblique memoir
fields.bodyText: Alison Light’s last book, the Samuel Johnson-shortlisted Common People, was what she called “family history as public history”, using generations of her own working-class family as a lens through which to examine the social conditions that shaped them. In A Radical Romance she uses a similar approach to more recent and personal history – her 10-year marriage to the radical historian Raphael Samuel, until his death in 1996. She draws on her own extensive diaries and letters to offer a hybrid memoir that is at once a tribute to Samuel and his work, a portrait of a part of London in the grip of accelerated social change, and an account of love, frustration and grief. Perhaps inevitably, these different currents vie with one another for precedence, but Light is keenly aware of these tensions, interrogating her own process and the nature of memoir as history, “a history from inside”: “Memoir weaves its way between what is often called the private and the public, the personal as opposed to the historical… I find these terms far more porous than absolute.” Light married Samuel in 1987, when she was 30 and he 50. He was one of a breed now almost extinct, the public intellectual: well established as a historian, from a secular Jewish family, raised in the British Communist party, the author of numerous volumes of social history. She was a first-generation graduate from Portsmouth, with a teaching job at Brighton Polytechnic, who had abandoned an engagement to enjoy a kind of independence unknown to her mother’s generation: “My solitude was also shored up by the laws that had given women this relatively new freedom in British life. It depended on me renting or mortgaging under my own name and being left to live alone unmolested, on free and available contraception and the possibility of paid work.” “Feminism,” she writes, “like writing, was a wedge prising my life open.” Yet her romance with Samuel created an abrupt change of direction. “Falling in love is a mystery that only in retrospect becomes blindingly obvious: how could I not have fallen for him? I ask myself years later. But what makes us take that leap?” It is a question she does not answer wholly satisfactorily. Samuel was clearly enormously charismatic; within weeks he had proposed and Light moved into his busy, book-filled house in Spitalfields. Shortly after the wedding, she has a kind of breakdown, and here the tensions between the different modes of the book become most strained. The way she writes about this feels frustratingly oblique, at least to a reader acclimatised to a more confessional type of memoir, as if the desire to examine her own experience meets a reluctance to speak too critically of her late husband. It seems clear that the way her life becomes subsumed into his, creating an increasing sense of isolation and questioning of identity, is the catalyst for her collapse. Samuel – raised to dismiss the idea of the self – tells her that her depression is an “honourable” response to the gentrification of Spitalfields, east London. Gradually they find accommodation with a shared life, until the shock of his cancer diagnosis at 61. The real heart of the book is the final third, Mourning; though written at 20 years’ distance from the grief it describes, this section allows an intimacy that feels absent from previous sections, which deliberately turn away from the overly personal to broaden into wider social history. Here she writes with precision and tenderness about loss, and how the conflict between the public and private self is made concrete when the dead person has left behind an archive that must be preserved. “Sorrow, like guilt, never ends, though it ebbs and flows,” she writes. “I have never ‘got over’ Raphael’s death; it sliced my life in two.” A Radical Romance is an admirable tribute to a man, a period of rapid change in London, and an unusual marriage, but I wish that the author had stepped out of his shadow more often. • A Radical Romance: A Memoir of Love, Grief and Consolation by Alison Light is published by Penguin Fig Tree (£20). To order a copy go to guardianbookshop.com. Free UK p&p over £15
